FacilityName: City Of Norfolk East Water Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The City of Norfolk Water Division is comprised of two (2) Water Treatment Plants and a staff of 15

employees.  This includes the West Water Treatment Plant located at 300 South 49th Street and the

East Water Treatment Plant located at 111 South 1st Street.



1.  Accidential Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy - Water Staff is trained on safe

chlorine operating and handling procedures.  Staff also performs monthly preventive maintenance and

checks on the chlorination, chlorine scrubber, and leak detection systems.  The Emergency Response Plan

includes procedures for notification of the Norfolk Fire Division, which activates the Local Emergency 

Operations Plan (LEOP) and notifies any potential neighbors.  Norfolk Fire Division is a member of the

Elkhorn Valley LEPC.



2.  Regulated Substances - The East Water Treatment Plant uses chlorine as a disinfectant.  We have 

one (1) one ton chlorine cylinder on at all times.  We could have another one (1) one ton cylinders on hand

at any given time for a total of two (2) one ton cylinders on site.



3.  A) Worst Case Scenario - A possible broken cylinder valve on a one ton chlorine cylinder will release

chlorine gas.  Chlorine gas can travel a distance of 1.3 miles  If this type of leakage would occur, we

would activate the Emergency Response Team to protect the residents in the affected area.  Next step, 

we would notify Chem Trec Response Team.



    B) Alternative Release Scenario - A leaking lead gasket that seals an attached line onto the regulator

could possibly release a chlorine vapor cloud ata rate of 15 lbs. Per minute.  This cloud could travel a 

distance of 0.10 miles.  The chlorine cylinders are stored inside a concrete building and are monitored 

by a chlorine gas detection system.  When the detection system detects 1.5 ppm of chlorine gas, the 

emergency chlorine scrubber system will become active.  If this type of scenario would occur trained

staff and emergency scrubber can

migrate the off site consequences.



4.  Five Year Accident History - We have not had any accidential releases in the last five years using

one ton chlorine cylinders.



5.  Emergency Response Program - Our Emergency Response Program is to utilize an on-site chlorine

scrubber which is activated when chlorine gas is detected.  The scrubber has the ability to consume

a one ton chlorine cylinder within 25 minutes.  Water Treatment Staff is also trained and ready to 

respond to a chlorine leak.  In the event of a leak the Water Treatment Staff would activate the 

Emergency Plan, which includes procedures for notification of the Norfolk Fire Division.  Norfolk Fire

Division would activate the Local Emergency Operations Plan (LEOP) and notifies any affected 

neighbors.  Norfok Fire Division is also a member of the Elkhorn Valley LEPC, which assists with Chem

Trec, and other agencies that initiates response from a HAZMAT Team.



6.  Planned Changes To Improve Safety - We will keep up with the latest technology for safe chlorine

use ans update procedures as needed.
